misconceptions.name: Implemented a different triangle problem (area from coordinates) instead of pattern printing
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the area of a triangle from three coordinate points using Heron's formula, instead of reading a height N and printing a right triangle of asterisks as specified.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that asks for three points of a triangle and computes its area.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single height N from the user and print N lines where line i contains i asterisks, forming a right triangle pattern. It should not compute geometric area or read coordinates.
symptoms: Program prompts for three coordinate points instead of a single height N
No loops to produce multiple rows of output
Output is a numeric area value, not a triangle of asterisks
No use of '*' characters in the output
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different triangle-related exercises or reuse of code from a previous problem that computed triangle area instead of a text-based pattern.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and start from scratch: prompt once for an integer height N, then use a loop (or nested loops) so that the first line prints 1 '*', the second line 2 '*', and so on up to N, with a newline after each row.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program focuses on computing triangle area from coordinates and there is no code related to reading N or printing a star pattern.

evidence.note: Reads three coordinate pairs instead of a single integer height N, indicating the student is solving a different problem.
Computes and prints triangle area using Heron's formula; no logic for printing a right triangle pattern of asterisks.
Entire program structure centers on geometric distance and area; there are no loops or '*' characters to form the required right triangle output.

misconceptions.name: Completely wrong program solved
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the area of a triangle using Heron's formula based on three user-provided points (x, y coordinates), instead of solving the assigned problem: printing a right triangle pattern of asterisks based on a provided height N.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have solved an entirely different programming problem (calculating triangle area using 3 points/Heron's formula) instead of the requested pattern printing problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requested program required reading a single integer N (the height) and using nested loops to print an asterisk pattern, not calculating geometry properties.
symptoms: Code input prompts for coordinates (x1, y1), (x2, y2), (x3, y3)
Code calculates side lengths and area using the distance formula and Heron's formula
No loops are present for printing patterns
The class name suggests a different task (TriangleAreaHeron)
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding or confusion about the assignment requirements, resulting in the submission of code for a completely different task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully. Ignore the submitted code and implement the logic for drawing patterns using iteration (loops) and obtaining the required height N from the user.
related_concepts: Printing to the console (System.out.print vs System.out.println)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code clearly solves a geometry problem (Heron's formula) and contains none of the elements required for the pattern printing problem (loops, reading N, printing asterisks). This is a direct substitution of one program for another.

evidence.note: The class name indicates a different program goal.
Input is for three points, not a single height N.
The core logic calculates area using geometry formulas, not pattern printing.

misconceptions.name: Completely wrong problem implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating triangle area using Heron's formula with coordinate points, rather than reading a height N and printing a right triangle pattern of asterisks.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a different problem - one that involves calculating the area of a triangle given three coordinate points using Heron's formula.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading a single integer N from the user, then printing N rows where row i contains i asterisks, forming a right triangle pattern.
symptoms: Program prompts for three coordinate points instead of a height
Program calculates and prints a triangle area instead of printing an asterisk pattern
No loop structure exists to generate multiple rows
No asterisk printing logic present
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either misread the problem statement, submitted code from a different assignment, or confused this problem with a different triangle-related problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem carefully. The task requires reading ONE integer (height N), then using nested loops to print N rows where row i has i asterisks. Focus on the loop structure and string repetition.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves an entirely different problem (Heron's formula triangle area) rather than printing an asterisk triangle pattern. There is no overlap between the two problems.

evidence.note: Program prompts for three coordinate points instead of a single height value as required by Q4.
Program calculates triangle area using Heron's formula instead of printing an asterisk pattern. No nested loops exist for printing rows of asterisks.

misconceptions.task: Correct pattern (1 star to N stars)
misconceptions.name: Implemented triangle area calculation instead of star pattern printing
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program that reads coordinates of a triangle's vertices and computes its area using Heron's formula, instead of printing a right triangle of asterisks with N rows as specified in the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should solve a geometry problem: read three points of a triangle and compute its area.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read a single height N and use loops to print N rows of a right triangle made of '*' characters, from 1 star in the first row up to N stars in the last row.
symptoms: Program never reads a height N
No loops that generate rows or columns of '*' characters
Output is a numeric area value, not a triangle pattern
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the assignment or reuse of code for a different triangle-related task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the geometry/area logic and instead write a fresh program that reads an integer N and uses nested loops to print rows of '*' from 1 to N.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is dedicated to computing triangle area from coordinates with no code related to star patterns or loops for printing.

evidence.note: All logic focuses on reading triangle coordinates and computing area; there is no code for printing a '*' triangle pattern.

misconceptions.name: Reads multiple coordinate values instead of a single integer height
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading a single integer height N for the triangle, the program reads six double values representing three (x, y) points.
misconceptions.student_belief: The program needs to read three points (x1, y1), (x2, y2), and (x3, y3) as doubles from input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly one integer value N from the user, representing the height (number of rows) of the star triangle.
symptoms: Multiple calls to nextDouble() instead of a single read for N
No variable representing height or number of rows
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about what input the assignment requires, likely due to copying or focusing on a different triangle problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace all coordinate inputs with a single read, e.g., `System.out.print("Enter height: "); int N = input.nextInt();` and use N in your loops for printing.
related_concepts: Choosing appropriate variable types for input
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only input operations are six nextDouble() calls for coordinates, and there is no mention of a height or N variable.

evidence.note: Shows the program reading six doubles for three points instead of a single integer height N as required.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the area of a triangle using Heron's formula (requiring coordinate input), instead of implementing the assignment's requirement (printing an asterisk triangle pattern based on a height N input).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have solved an entirely different math problem (Triangle Area calculation) than the pattern printing problem required by the assignment (Print a Right Triangle).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The correct program should read a single integer N (the height) and use nested loops to print exactly N rows of asterisks, with the i-th row having i asterisks.
symptoms: Code reads six coordinate inputs (x1, y1, etc.) instead of one integer height N.
Code contains mathematical formulas (distance, area) instead of pattern-printing loops.
Code solves a geometry problem instead of a loop/pattern problem.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment requirement or submitting code for the wrong problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment description for Q4 (Print a Right Triangle) and ensure your code uses loops to generate the required output pattern.
related_concepts: Reading input from the keyboard (integer vs. coordinates)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The supplied code is completely implemented to solve a different problem (Triangle Area calculation) and contains none of the elements required by the rubric for pattern printing.

evidence.note: The entire code implements a solution for calculating triangle area, not printing an asterisk pattern. It reads coordinate doubles instead of an integer height N.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (calculating triangle area using Heron's formula) rather than printing a right triangle pattern with asterisks.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this code solves the right triangle pattern printing problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single integer N and printing N rows of asterisks in a triangle pattern (1 star, 2 stars, ..., N stars), not calculating triangle area from coordinate points.
symptoms: Code requests three coordinate pairs instead of a single height value
Code performs mathematical calculations instead of printing patterns
Output is a numerical area value, not a triangle of asterisks
No loop structures for pattern generation
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misunderstanding of assignment requirements, possible copy-paste from wrong problem, or submission of incorrect file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment specification carefully. Write a new program that: (1) reads one integer N, (2) uses nested loops to print N rows, (3) prints i asterisks in row i, and (4) includes proper newlines after each row.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is unambiguously solving a different problem. The method signatures, input/output, and logic are entirely unrelated to the assigned task.

evidence.note: Code requests three coordinate points instead of a single height integer N.

evidence.snippet:
double area = Math.sqrt(s * (s - side1) * (s - side2) * (s - side3));

System.out.println("The area of the triangle is " + area);
evidence.note: Code outputs a numerical area calculation, not a pattern of asterisks.
Code contains helper method for distance calculations (Heron's formula), unrelated to triangle pattern printing.
